abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. The use of a
            one-tranche operation provided good support to a pending
            reform agenda, particularly when, during the last period of
            an outgoing administration, no compliance with tranche
            conditions remained for the new government to implement. The
            lessons indicate that, although the reform program was
            largely successful, three measures might have improved the
            implementation, and sustainability of reforms: 1) a stronger
            public awareness campaign could have been built into the
            program, to emphasize the rationale for reform, which in
            turn would have increased public support, particularly in
            Panama, where interventionist policies, and benefits of
            competition, and market-oriented policies have had limited
            acceptance; 2) the Government, with the support of the Bank,
            should have addressed the needs of poor producers -
            negatively affected by the trade reform program - by clearly
            devising a strategy to minimize the transitional impact,
            while non-competitive farmers should have been encouraged to
            shift to other economic activities; 3) while the difficulty
            of reducing the share of public expenditure in an election
            year could have been foreseen, and adjusted, it is fair to
            say that realistic fiscal assumptions could have led to
            better planning, and phasing of subsequent budget cuts.
